column4: i don't know why, but "sudo aptitude install unrar *" removed a lot of packages before installing
i said no asterisk
it was a typo correction, to build off my previous statement
i did it with asterisk, have i done any damage to my system?
well... what did it say it removed?
this is it http://paste.ubuntu.com/351673/ any bad news for me?
looking now
im not quite sure what the asterisk means to aptitude
im referring to the documentation to see how it interprets the *
thank you for your assistance
documentation doesn't say much about the * in the command
based on what i've seen, it removed some KDE support (your desktop environment ?) I'd aptitude install those packages back.
also some xmms (music player) and some bitorrent related apps
i don't see anything vital that would make me freak out
you could always tell by doing a reboot
and see if the system comes back up gracefully ;)
sure i'll be here ;)
cool ;)
always give the fellas here a few seconds extra, to follow up their statements, try to avoid knee-jerk reactions ;)
now i should use unrar through the terminal or not?
exactly, pick one file in the set, example, unrar -e aaaa.r01
or what Surlent777 said, unrar is available by right clicking on an archive, and clicking "extract here"
i think the command line unrar is more useful, it will tell you which .rar is missing in a set, if there's one that's corrupt or missing, more verbose than the GUI operation
to each his/her own though ;)
